verbatim.solution_statement: As far as possible, avoid the use of corridors and passages. Instead, use public rooms and common rooms as rooms for movement and for gathering. To do this, place the common rooms to form a chain, or loop, so that it becomes possible to walk from room to room—and so that private rooms open directly off these public rooms. In every case, give this indoor circulation from room to room a feeling of great generosity, passing in a wide and ample loop around the house, with views of fires and great windows.

forces.name: movement efficiency vs. spatial vitality
forces.pole_a: the need to move efficiently through a building from room to room
forces.pole_b: the need for rooms to feel alive, inhabited, and connected rather than sterile
forces.description: Dedicated corridors solve circulation efficiently but drain life from a building; routing movement through shared rooms resolves this by making circulation itself a social act
forces.resolved_by: placing common rooms in a chain or loop so that movement passes through them rather than beside them

forces.name: privacy vs. connection
forces.pole_a: the need for private rooms to be sheltered and undisturbed
forces.pole_b: the need for rooms to feel connected to the larger life of the building
forces.description: Private rooms must be reachable without exposing them to through-traffic, while still remaining integrated with communal life
forces.resolved_by: private rooms open directly off the public loop rooms, so they are accessible without being traversed

forces.name: generous circulation vs. compact plan
forces.pole_a: the desire for wide, ample, looping paths that feel generous and inviting
forces.pole_b: the practical pressure to minimise wasted floor area in a building
forces.description: Generous circulation requires space; compact planning resists it — the pattern resolves this by making circulation space do double duty as habitable common room space
forces.resolved_by: common and public rooms serve simultaneously as gathering space and circulation path, eliminating wasted corridor area

forces.name: directionality vs. freedom of movement
forces.pole_a: a linear chain of rooms that creates clear sequential movement
forces.pole_b: the ability to approach destinations from multiple directions and move freely
forces.description: A simple chain of rooms forces one-way passage; a loop liberates occupants to come and go in two directions
forces.resolved_by: forming rooms in a loop so that circulation is always reversible and multi-directional

typed_rules.rationale: Corridors isolate movement from communal life and make buildings feel dead
typed_rules.source_text: As far as possible, avoid the use of corridors and passages.

typed_rules.rationale: Only a chain or loop allows rooms to serve simultaneously as circulation and gathering space
typed_rules.source_text: place the common rooms to form a chain, or loop, so that it becomes possible to walk from room to room

typed_rules.preferred_value: open directly off public/common loop rooms
typed_rules.rationale: Private rooms must be reachable from common rooms without requiring passage through other private rooms
typed_rules.source_text: private rooms open directly off these public rooms

typed_rules.preferred_value: wide, ample, generous loop with views of fires and great windows
typed_rules.rationale: Generous circulation encourages use and social encounter rather than mere transit
typed_rules.source_text: give this indoor circulation from room to room a feeling of great generosity, passing in a wide and ample loop around the house, with views of fires and great windows

typed_rules.preferred_value: wide, furnished like rooms, placed on one building side, filled with light
typed_rules.rationale: When corridors cannot be avoided they should be made habitable rather than merely functional
typed_rules.source_text: Whenever passages or corridors are unavoidable, make them wide and generous too; and try to place them on one side of the building, so that they can be filled with light—Furnish them like rooms, with carpets, bookshelves, easy chairs and tables, filtered light

typed_rules.preferred_value: full loop preferred over simple chain; chain with parallel passage acceptable
typed_rules.rationale: A loop allows two-directional movement and ties rooms together most generously; a chain with parallel passage achieves similar effect where a full loop is impractical
typed_rules.source_text: Even better, is the case where there is a loop. A loop, which passes through all the major rooms, public and common, establishes an enormous feeling of generosity.

typed_rules.rationale: Corner doors preserve the usable area of room walls and minimise disruption to room activities by keeping through-movement to the periphery
typed_rules.source_text: Keep doors which open into rooms, or doors between rooms which create the flow through rooms, in the corners of the rooms—CORNER DOORS (196)

adjacency_rules.note: When corridors are unavoidable, Short Passages specifies how to make them wide, light-filled, and positioned on one building side
Entrance Room should be furnished and treated like a room for movement, integrated with the flow-through system
Staircase should be treated as a room for movement in the same spirit as the flow-through pattern
Rooms for movement should have views to animate and reward passage through them
Flow-through rooms should be filled with plenty of light to make circulation inviting

adjacency_rules.target_pattern_name: Light on Two Sides of Every Room
adjacency_rules.note: Rooms used for movement and gathering should have light from two sides
Doors between rooms that create the flow-through must be placed in corners to preserve room integrity

failure_modes.description: When corridors are used instead of common rooms for circulation, the building feels dead and the corridor space is wasted — movement becomes purely functional transit with no social dimension.
failure_modes.symptom: Corridors go unused except for transit; common rooms lose vitality because people pass beside them rather than through them
failure_modes.source_text: As far as possible, avoid the use of corridors and passages.

failure_modes.description: When common rooms are arranged in a dead-end chain without a loop or parallel passage, occupants must retrace their path to exit, and the rooms feel isolated and poorly connected.
failure_modes.symptom: Movement becomes one-directional; rooms at the end of the chain feel remote and cut off; the building loses a sense of generosity
failure_modes.source_text: A loop, which passes through all the major rooms, public and common, establishes an enormous feeling of generosity. With a loop it is always possible to come and go in two different directions.

failure_modes.description: When private rooms can only be reached by passing through other private rooms, privacy is destroyed and movement constantly disturbs occupants.
failure_modes.symptom: Bedrooms or work rooms are interrupted by through-traffic; occupants cannot be reached without disturbing others
failure_modes.source_text: private rooms open directly off these public rooms

failure_modes.description: When unavoidable passages are left narrow, dark, and unfurnished, they become oppressive and undermine the feeling of generosity that the pattern requires throughout the building.
failure_modes.symptom: Corridors feel institutional and uninviting; occupants hurry through rather than lingering; the building feels mean rather than generous
failure_modes.source_text: Whenever passages or corridors are unavoidable, make them wide and generous too; and try to place them on one side of the building, so that they can be filled with light—Furnish them like rooms, with carpets, bookshelves, easy chairs and tables, filtered light
